title: 104_hr4188
content:
The Act titled "Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System Act of 1995" is established for the purpose of providing findings and purposes. The Fort Peck Reservation in Montana lacks sufficient water supplies that meet health and safety standards, posing a threat to public health. The United States has a responsibility to provide adequate and safe water supplies to the reservation, with the Missouri River identified as the best source. The purpose of the Act is to ensure a safe and adequate water supply for the reservation. The purpose of the Act is to ensure a safe and adequate water supply for the residents of the Fort Peck Indian Reservation in Montana. SEC. 3. FORT PECK RESERVATION RURAL WATER SYSTEM. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to plan, design, construct, operate, maintain, and replace the Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System, including pumping and treatment facilities, pipelines throughout the reservation, and future interconnections to surrounding communities. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to plan, design, construct, operate, maintain, and replace the Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System, including facilities for distribution and treatment in communities like Plentywood, Scobey, Flaxville, and Culbertson. This includes purchasing, improving, and repairing existing water systems on the Fort Peck Indian Reservation, along with necessary property rights, access roads, and electrical power facilities. Additional pipelines, pumping plants, and storage facilities may also be included to meet water supply, economic, public health, and environmental needs. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to enter into cooperative agreements with the Fort Peck Tribal Executive Board for planning, designing, constructing, operating, maintaining, and replacing the Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System, including water storage tanks, water lines, and other facilities for reservation villages, towns, and municipalities. The cooperative agreements with the Fort Peck Tribal Executive Board cover engineering, design, construction, water conservation measures, and contract administration. They also include approval procedures, acceptance requirements, and delineate rights, responsibilities, and liabilities of each party. The agreements may involve purchasing, improving, and repairing existing water systems on the Fort Peck Indian Reservation. The Secretary has the authority to unilaterally terminate any agreement if construction quality fails to meet established standards. Upon execution of any cooperative agreement authorized under this section, the Secretary is authorized to transfer funds to the Fort Peck Tribes for the Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System. The service area of the system includes the Fort Peck Indian Reservation and surrounding communities. Construction requirements include pumping plants, pipelines, treatment facilities, and other necessary infrastructure. The Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System will be planned and constructed to meet water supply needs, with title held in trust for the tribes. Construction funds are contingent on meeting environmental requirements. The Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System will be planned and constructed to meet water supply needs, with title held in trust for the tribes. Construction funds are contingent on meeting environmental requirements. The Secretary is authorized to provide technical assistance for the development and operation of the water supply system. The system will be subject to the Indian Self-Determination Act. SEC. 4. WATER CONSERVATION PROGRAMS.

Prior to construction funds being obligated, the Secretary must ensure that the Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System includes water conservation measures that are economically feasible. The Fort Peck Tribes will develop a water conservation plan with specific goals and a timeline. Users of the water supply system must utilize the best technology and management practices to conserve water. SEC 5. USE OF PICK-SLOAN POWER. The Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System will use power from Pick-Sloan for operation, deemed a project use pumping requirement. Power reserved for future project use pumping will be available at the wholesale firm power rate for Pick-Sloan. The Administrator of the Western Area Power Administration can purchase additional power if needed to meet pumping requirements. The Administrator can purchase additional power for the Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System at wholesale firm power rate for Pick-Sloan. Expenses for power purchases will be recovered through a separate power charge applied to the System. Definitions for "System" and "Pick Sloan" are provided. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of $114,734,300 for planning, design, and construction of Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System, with funds available for five years. Additional funds may be adjusted for development costs. Authorization for operation and maintenance of the system as needed. Authorization for operation and maintenance of the Fort Peck Reservation Rural Water System. SEC. 7. WATER RIGHTS. Nothing in sections 1 through 12 shall impair State water law or interstate compacts, alter State water rights, preempt water quality laws, confer Federal water rights to non-Federal entities, or affect water rights of the Fort Peck Tribes. The Fort Peck Indian Reservation's water rights are based on various legal sources, including treaties, compacts, executive orders, and Acts of Congress. The Winters doctrine is also relevant. This section does not confirm or deny the existence, nonexistence, or extinguishment of water rights held by the Fort Peck Tribes or other Indian tribes under Federal or State law.
